title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) — The box score will tell you the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Toronto Raptors 106-84. The history books, however, will tell the true story: this was the night Steve Smith authored a masterpiece.

From the opening tip, Smith was a man possessed, operating with a cold-blooded efficiency that left the Raptors scrambling. He didn't just score; he orchestrated the entire offensive symphony for the Hawks, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 46 points in a performance for the ages. Each basket was a methodical dismantling of the Toronto defense, a blend of silky jumpers and powerful drives that seemed utterly unstoppable.

While the Raptors, led by Damon Stoudamire's 18 points, searched for answers that never came, Smith’s singular brilliance was more than enough. His historic output single-handedly outstripped the entire output of multiple Raptors starters combined. The Hawks’ supporting cast, with Dikembe Mutombo anchoring the paint with 14 rebounds, played their roles perfectly, feeding the hot hand and watching a legend be born in real time.

The final buzzer signaled more than just a 22-point victory; it cemented a piece of Hawks lore. On this night, the collective effort of a basketball game was overshadowed by the sheer force of one man's will. Steve Smith didn't just win a game; he seized his moment and carved his name into the record books with an unforgettable 46-point explosion that will echo through the annals of Atlanta basketball history.
